messageBody:
On 9/21/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
> Robert Watkins wrote:
>
> > Certain output streams automatically convert \n to the line seperator
> > of the platform you are on.
>
> Really? Which ones? That's certainly not standard behavior, and it's not
> true of System.out, which is the stream at issue here.

Actually, it's the writers, not the output streams that do this. Sorry
for not being precise. (OutputStreams wouldn't do this because they
operate at a byte level). Not all the writers do it either... I forget
which ones (though I suspect it's probably FileWriter)

For the code under question, it's hard to tell without knowing what
the function call does, but note that the println() family of methods
for PrintStream _do_ use the System property.

> In general code should not be written to depend on the system line
> separator. That worked well when programs and data spent their entire
> lives on one computer, or perhaps a few computers all running the same
> OS. In the world of the Internet and Java, that's no longer true.
> Programs should explicitly specify the line separator character(s) they
> write or read. Their output should not vary from one platform to the next.

That's not strictly true, Elliotte. It depends on the nature of what
you are doing. In particular, when writing to files, then you should
respect the line seperator, otherwise the text-editing tools of the
platform will have problems.

Similarly, with console output (the case in point), you should use the
correct line seperator, otherwise the console may not render the
output correctly.

Of course, if you are writing a network application, then you should
use a fixed line seperator, which by convention would be '\n'.

Similary with character encoding, you should use the platform default
if you are writing for human output (e.g. files, console, or display),
but should use a standard convention like UTF-8 or UTF-16 when
transmitting.
